SCHOLARSHIP AND EDUCATION
It has been several months now since our editorial column has
contained an exchange, but even if we had been guilty of over-using
the privilege, the following editorial noted in the Rutgers "Targum- so meets our approval that we reproduce it here for your
perusal:
"Too many students go through their entire college course with
the idea that on the completion of their book work they will step out
into a world where things will just naturally happen for their success. Even the man who is working his way through school and,
incidentally, holding a practical job often misunderstands the real
value of studies. So many acknowledge the worth of a college education and exert every effort to obtain one without ever determining
just wherein lies its value. Most every intelligent man admits that
a course of study which develops the mental machine to concentrate
on problems and solve them efficiently is invaluable. But too much
should not be expected of this mental ability alone.
"Learn to observe people, especially successful business men,
and to know their reasons for success. The student should seek to
analyze every business with which he comes in contact in order to
determine just what are the important points in that business. Of
course, the entire organization assists, but in every concern there
are one or two vital spots, the proper functioning of which determine
its success.
"Keep an eye on world affairs and conditions outside the classroom and as you acquire each successive bit of knowledge, try to
visualize its practical application."
Such powers of observation are not gained by devotion to textbooks alone. The real value of participation in campus activities
lies in the development of powers of observation, leadership and,
above all, the development in the individual of a confidence in himself.
High scholarship alone is truly a one-sided development. Know
yourself and learn the world—that is the real purpose of a college
education.

BANQUET TIME
Banquet time! How little that means to the outside world, but how
much it means to the college man. To the uninformed public a banquet
means a period of gastronomic exercise and (for the last few years)
a sorrowing of the past.
To the college senior, the class banquet means his fond farewell
to four years of real joy; a last fling at collegiate celebration and a
denunciation of the Volstead Act over his cups.
To the Junior, banquet night means the first real crack at unrestrained pleasure, free from fears of a rival class attack.
To the Sophomore and the Freshman the celebration calls for
pitched battle and kidnapping of the rival class' officers. Thoughts of
just such a battle on the shores of the Magothy and in the hills of Port
Deposit are sweet to the memory of the present Senior Class.
Interclass conflict is desirable to the traditions of Hopkins, but tlE.
leaders should be on guard to check any over-zealous classmate who
would overdo his privilege. Pitched battle, in as far as possible, should
be held out-of-doors, where no furniture or glass windows might be
smashed.
Use your judgment, lads, and go to it. Boys will be boys, but in
several years they must be staid business men, so get it out of your
system in the two or three years that remain..

FTER the big game, if you don't need a box of voice
lozenges there's something wrong. A hoarse voice is
evidence that you are covering your position on the bleachers.
The harder the game the harder it ought to be to talk
afterwards. Your "Ataboy" and "Line it out" buck up a
fagged nine—and so your shouts give you the right to rejoice
in the victory, because they helped to win it.
This spectacle of a grandstand full of men fighting for
their team is one aspect of a very splendid sentiment—
college spirit.
When you show college spirit you are doing a fine thing
for your college, a fine thing for the men around you, but a
finer thing for yourself. You are developing a quality which,
if carried into the business world, will help you to success.
The same spirit which keeps you cheering through a rainy
afternoon will in after life keep you up all night to put
through a rush job for the boss.
The same spirit which makes you stand by your teams
through thick and thin will find you loyal to your shop or
office, always ready with a shoulder to the wheel—even if it
isn't your own particular wheel—giving suggestion and active
help and a word of good cheer, once again earning your
right to rejoice in the victory.
In business as in college make it a good,snappy "Yea,team!"

department of physics, including a
lecture room and several laboratories.

SCHOLARSHIP AND EDUCATION
It has been several months now since our editorial column has
contained an exchange, but even if we had been guilty of over-using
the privilege, the following editorial noted in the Rutgers "Targum- so meets our approval that we reproduce it here for your
perusal:
"Too many students go through their entire college course with
the idea that on the completion of their book work they will step out
into a world where things will just naturally happen for their success. Even the man who is working his way through school and,
incidentally, holding a practical job often misunderstands the real
value of studies. So many acknowledge the worth of a college education and exert every effort to obtain one without ever determining
just wherein lies its value. Most every intelligent man admits that
a course of study which develops the mental machine to concentrate
on problems and solve them efficiently is invaluable. But too much
should not be expected of this mental ability alone.
"Learn to observe people, especially successful business men,
and to know their reasons for success. The student should seek to
analyze every business with which he comes in contact in order to
determine just what are the important points in that business. Of
course, the entire organization assists, but in every concern there
are one or two vital spots, the proper functioning of which determine
its success.
"Keep an eye on world affairs and conditions outside the classroom and as you acquire each successive bit of knowledge, try to
visualize its practical application."
Such powers of observation are not gained by devotion to textbooks alone. The real value of participation in campus activities
lies in the development of powers of observation, leadership and,
above all, the development in the individual of a confidence in himself.
High scholarship alone is truly a one-sided development. Know
yourself and learn the world—that is the real purpose of a college
education.

BANQUET TIME
Banquet time! How little that means to the outside world, but how
much it means to the college man. To the uninformed public a banquet
means a period of gastronomic exercise and (for the last few years)
a sorrowing of the past.
To the college senior, the class banquet means his fond farewell
to four years of real joy; a last fling at collegiate celebration and a
denunciation of the Volstead Act over his cups.
To the Junior, banquet night means the first real crack at unrestrained pleasure, free from fears of a rival class attack.
To the Sophomore and the Freshman the celebration calls for
pitched battle and kidnapping of the rival class' officers. Thoughts of
just such a battle on the shores of the Magothy and in the hills of Port
Deposit are sweet to the memory of the present Senior Class.
Interclass conflict is desirable to the traditions of Hopkins, but tlE.
leaders should be on guard to check any over-zealous classmate who
would overdo his privilege. Pitched battle, in as far as possible, should
be held out-of-doors, where no furniture or glass windows might be
smashed.
Use your judgment, lads, and go to it. Boys will be boys, but in
several years they must be staid business men, so get it out of your
system in the two or three years that remain..

FTER the big game, if you don't need a box of voice
lozenges there's something wrong. A hoarse voice is
evidence that you are covering your position on the bleachers.
The harder the game the harder it ought to be to talk
afterwards. Your "Ataboy" and "Line it out" buck up a
fagged nine—and so your shouts give you the right to rejoice
in the victory, because they helped to win it.
This spectacle of a grandstand full of men fighting for
their team is one aspect of a very splendid sentiment—
college spirit.
When you show college spirit you are doing a fine thing
for your college, a fine thing for the men around you, but a
finer thing for yourself. You are developing a quality which,
if carried into the business world, will help you to success.
The same spirit which keeps you cheering through a rainy
afternoon will in after life keep you up all night to put
through a rush job for the boss.
The same spirit which makes you stand by your teams
through thick and thin will find you loyal to your shop or
office, always ready with a shoulder to the wheel—even if it
isn't your own particular wheel—giving suggestion and active
help and a word of good cheer, once again earning your
right to rejoice in the victory.
In business as in college make it a good,snappy "Yea,team!"

department of physics, including a
lecture room and several laboratories.
